I am writing on behalf of the Beer Institute, a trade association of brewers, beer importers, and industry suppliers regarding the Department's proposal to...
sourceClass: Business and Commerce, Politics and Government
text:
WASHINGTON, June 4 \-- Jim McGreevy, president and CEO of the Beer Institute,
has issued a public comment on the International Trade Administration's
proposed rule entitled "Aluminum Import Monitoring and Analysis System". The
comment was written on May 29, 2020, and posted on June 1, 2020:

* * *

I am writing on behalf of the Beer Institute (BI), a trade association of
brewers, beer importers, and industry suppliers regarding the Department's
proposal to establish a system of import licensing to facilitate the
monitoring of imports of aluminum articles, including monitoring for import
surges.

The United States beer industry is a heavy user of aluminum. Better than 60%
of the beer manufactured and sold in this country comes in aluminum cans and
bottles. We support the establishment of a system to check imports of aluminum
articles into this country, albeit in a slightly different form from the
system currently proposed.

The beer industry's experience with purchases of aluminum cans (body, end, and
tab) since the implementation of the Section 232 tariff may be instructive as
the Department considers setting up a monitoring system. First, with the
implementation of tariffs, available supplies of scrap aluminum increased.
Although increased use of lower-cost, tariff-exempt scrap would ordinarily
lower the price of cansheet, the beer industry saw the opposite marketplace
response with the tariff. The price of all aluminum cansheet, both imported
and domestic, and premiums associated with purchase of cansheet increased.
Prices have fallen since then, but because of slow demand for an expanding
global glut of metal.

Second, with the implementation of tariffs, the beer industry, indeed the
entire universe of U.S. end-users of aluminum, had to pay a specific premium,
the Midwest Premium Duty-Paid (MWP-DP), which includes a charge for the
tariff. The MWP-DP is what producers, including cansheet manufacturers,
require end-users to pay regardless of whether a tariff attaches to the metal.
For example, even though scrap, which is exempt from 232 tariffs, accounts for
70% or more of the content of cansheet, the MWP-DP attaches to the whole
purchase. Since March 2018, when Section 232 tariffs went into effect, the
U.S. beverage industry bought 3.06 million mton of cansheet, the content of
which was at least 70% tariff-exempt scrap. The U.S. beverage industry paid
$582 million in tariffs on this cansheet, mostly factored as a part of the
MWP-DP. The U.S. Government received only $81 million in actual tariff
payments on these cansheet purchases. In other words, 86% of the Section 232
tariffs built into the MWP-DP went to private parties, not the U.S.
Government. Of the $582 million in Section 232 charges, $541 million or 86%
were also for non-tariffed metal, including scrap, domestic primary aluminum,
or primary aluminum from Canada and other countries exempt from Section 232
tariffs.

Third, cansheet manufacturers shifted their production from the United States
to other countries. The beer industry prefers buying domestically, but
cansheet manufacturers saw lower-cost opportunities elsewhere. These changes
will increasingly affect the U.S. beer industry as domestic supply gives way
to a less certain imported supply. Further to this point, while some importers
of cansheet sought and received exclusions from Section 232 tariffs, end-users
like brewers still paid the MWP-DP and saw no benefit from those exclusions.

Fourth, as global production continues and manufacturing demands fall, we now
see efforts to prop up aluminum prices, including a declining Midwest Premium.
For example, earlier this month, S&P Global Platts suggested setting a "floor"
for the Midwest Premium to prevent it from falling into negative territory.
Although opposition from BI and others caused S&P Global Platts to rethink
this plan, we know calls for the elimination of country exemptions and sharp
restrictions on Section 232 exclusions as well as requests for increases in
Section 232 tariff rates are all designed to lead to the same result:
increased aluminum prices and premiums. We urge the Department to carefully
assess the likely negative effects of each proposed change on aluminum
endusers, particularly U.S. manufacturers already suffering the adverse
impacts of COVID-19 on their businesses.

The time has come for sunshine and facts. The United States needs a public
system of monitoring and disclosure of aluminum imports. Instead of aggregate
disclosures, however, we recommend public disclosures showing who exactly is
importing what from where. A system of complete public disclosures will show
facts about the nature and extent of actual imports into this country. It
would also help end-users push back against the price gouging they currently
experience. Equally important, public disclosures will supply objective facts
to use in assessing calls for further restrictions that may have harmful
impacts on end-users.

The Department should adopt a policy to publicly show import information in a
specific, not aggregate manner. Anything less will do little to address the
problems end-users of aluminum face both in terms of supply and tariff-
burdened pricing.

Respectfully submitted,

Jim McGreevy

President and CEO

* * *

The proposed rule can be viewed at:
<https://beta.regulations.gov/document/ITA_FRDOC_0001-6085>

title: Beer Institute Issues Public Comment on International Trade Administration Proposed Rule
html:
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Jim McGreevy, president and CEO of the Beer Institute, has issued a public comment on the International Trade Administration's proposed rule entitled "Aluminum Import Monitoring and Analysis System". The comment was written on May 29, 2020, and posted on June 1, 2020:

* * *

I am writing on behalf of the Beer Institute (BI), a trade association of brewers, beer importers, and industry suppliers regarding the Department's proposal to establish a system of import licensing to facilitate the monitoring of imports of aluminum articles, including monitoring for import surges.

The United States beer industry is a heavy user of aluminum. Better than 60% of the beer manufactured and sold in this country comes in aluminum cans and bottles. We support the establishment of a system to check imports of aluminum articles into this country, albeit in a slightly different form from the system currently proposed.

The beer industry's experience with purchases of aluminum cans (body, end, and tab) since the implementation of the Section 232 tariff may be instructive as the Department considers setting up a monitoring system. First, with the implementation of tariffs, available supplies of scrap aluminum increased. Although increased use of lower-cost, tariff-exempt scrap would ordinarily lower the price of cansheet, the beer industry saw the opposite marketplace response with the tariff. The price of all aluminum cansheet, both imported and domestic, and premiums associated with purchase of cansheet increased. Prices have fallen since then, but because of slow demand for an expanding global glut of metal.

Second, with the implementation of tariffs, the beer industry, indeed the entire universe of U.S. end-users of aluminum, had to pay a specific premium, the Midwest Premium Duty-Paid (MWP-DP), which includes a charge for the tariff. The MWP-DP is what producers, including cansheet manufacturers, require end-users to pay regardless of whether a tariff attaches to the metal. For example, even though scrap, which is exempt from 232 tariffs, accounts for 70% or more of the content of cansheet, the MWP-DP attaches to the whole purchase. Since March 2018, when Section 232 tariffs went into effect, the U.S. beverage industry bought 3.06 million mton of cansheet, the content of which was at least 70% tariff-exempt scrap. The U.S. beverage industry paid $582 million in tariffs on this cansheet, mostly factored as a part of the MWP-DP. The U.S. Government received only $81 million in actual tariff payments on these cansheet purchases. In other words, 86% of the Section 232 tariffs built into the MWP-DP went to private parties, not the U.S. Government. Of the $582 million in Section 232 charges, $541 million or 86% were also for non-tariffed metal, including scrap, domestic primary aluminum, or primary aluminum from Canada and other countries exempt from Section 232 tariffs.

Third, cansheet manufacturers shifted their production from the United States to other countries. The beer industry prefers buying domestically, but cansheet manufacturers saw lower-cost opportunities elsewhere. These changes will increasingly affect the U.S. beer industry as domestic supply gives way to a less certain imported supply. Further to this point, while some importers of cansheet sought and received exclusions from Section 232 tariffs, end-users like brewers still paid the MWP-DP and saw no benefit from those exclusions.

Fourth, as global production continues and manufacturing demands fall, we now see efforts to prop up aluminum prices, including a declining Midwest Premium. For example, earlier this month, S&P Global Platts suggested setting a "floor" for the Midwest Premium to prevent it from falling into negative territory. Although opposition from BI and others caused S&P Global Platts to rethink this plan, we know calls for the elimination of country exemptions and sharp restrictions on Section 232 exclusions as well as requests for increases in Section 232 tariff rates are all designed to lead to the same result: increased aluminum prices and premiums. We urge the Department to carefully assess the likely negative effects of each proposed change on aluminum endusers, particularly U.S. manufacturers already suffering the adverse impacts of COVID-19 on their businesses.

The time has come for sunshine and facts. The United States needs a public system of monitoring and disclosure of aluminum imports. Instead of aggregate disclosures, however, we recommend public disclosures showing who exactly is importing what from where. A system of complete public disclosures will show facts about the nature and extent of actual imports into this country. It would also help end-users push back against the price gouging they currently experience. Equally important, public disclosures will supply objective facts to use in assessing calls for further restrictions that may have harmful impacts on end-users.

The Department should adopt a policy to publicly show import information in a specific, not aggregate manner. Anything less will do little to address the problems end-users of aluminum face both in terms of supply and tariff-burdened pricing.

Respectfully submitted,

Jim McGreevy

President and CEO

* * *

The proposed rule can be viewed at: https://beta.regulations.gov/document/ITA_FRDOC_0001-6085

For more information contact MYRON STRUCK, editor, editor@targetednews.com, Springfield, Virginia; 703/304-1897; https://targetednews.com
